(4) The planning of the dam shall proceed through stages such as selecting the dam construction location, analyzing reservoir capacity, determining dam size (height), reviewing dam type, and reviewing auxiliary facilities, based on information and data already secured. 2.2 Agricultural Dam Storage Capacity 2. 2.1 Agricultural Dam Inflow (1) The inflow used in dam planning generally refers to the streamflow at the dam inflow point over a long period of time in the past. (2) Inflow data requires long-term data to determine dam storage capacity, but if this is not available, it can be calculated using a deterministic model or a stochastic model. (3) For dam planning in areas with high vulnerability to climate change impacts, future weather conditions can be considered for inflow estimation. However, the results of the agricultural, rural, and food industry climate change impact and vulnerability assessment carried out in accordance with Article 47-2 of the "Act on Agriculture, Rural Area and Food Industry" can be utilized. 2. 2.2 Water Delivery Capacity (1) Water delivery capacity refers to the storage capacity secured for water delivery purposes, such as agricultural, industrial, and domestic water use. For dams, it is determined based on the regulated water quantity for each irrigation period during a once-in-10-year drought event and the dam inflow. (2) Climate change impact on water delivery. When determining water delivery capacity for regions with high vulnerability, scientific future weather conditions can be considered. (3) Water delivery capacity shall be calculated by considering the water demand of paddy fields, domestic water, industrial water, aquaculture water, environmental water, and other agricultural water (field water, facility water, livestock water, etc.) in nearby rural areas. When calculating water delivery capacity, the overlap of water delivery capacity with existing dams, such as multipurpose dams and power generation dams, can be considered. (4) Water delivery capacity is calculated by finding the maximum value from the difference between the hydrograph of regulated water quantity for each irrigation period and the dam inflow hydrograph of the reference drought year, and adding the water loss (reservoir evaporation) at the dam. Here, the river flow of the reference drought year refers to the river flow of a once-in-10-year drought year. Water Delivery Capacity = Maximum Water Deficit + Agricultural Dam Loss = Max{Irrigation Period [Regulated Water Quantity - River Flow]} + Agricultural Dam Loss. Here, the agricultural dam loss is taken as 5% of the maximum water deficit. 2. 2.3 Environmental Water Capacity (1) Environmental water refers to the water needed for rural environment conservation, specifically the water required to maintain the minimum functions of river ecosystems in rural areas and to improve the environment. (2) The environmental water capacity should consider the downstream river's water use for living, industry, agriculture, environmental improvement, power generation, and water intake, and should take into account the downstream river maintenance flow to maintain the river's normal function and condition. (3) The environmental water capacity shall apply the larger value between the standard drought flow at the dam site and the environmental water volume needed for rural environment conservation. 2. 2.4 Flood Control Capacity (1) The flood control capacity of a dam refers to the additional storage capacity secured beyond the effective storage capacity required for agricultural water supply, in order to reduce flood damage in downstream areas caused by heavy rainfall, extreme rainfall, and abnormal rainfall. (2) In order to reduce damage to downstream areas caused by heavy rainfall, extreme rainfall, and abnormal rainfall, additional storage capacity for flood control can be secured beyond the effective storage capacity required for agricultural water supply. (3) Flood control capacity is determined by considering the downstream river and dam size, and a water level-specific operation plan for flood control is established. (4) It is desirable that the flood ratio (= reservoir flood control capacity / watershed area) of the flood control capacity be approximately 100mm or more; if it is below this level, it should be reviewed whether methods such as water gate opening control or natural regulation can be adopted. (5) For dams that do not secure flood control capacity, if there are cities, residential complexes, public facilities, etc. in the downstream area, and human and property damage is expected due to flooding in the event of a disaster, or if the topography is such that heavy rainfall has frequently occurred in the past and flooding is feared, emergency water gates or other discharge facilities can be installed for pre-regulation of water levels in preparation for abnormal floods. The scale of the pre-discharge facilities shall be determined by considering the dam size and the degree of flood damage in the downstream area, but shall be installed to be able to lower the flood-limited water level within at least 3 days. (6) In the case of a dam, the discharge volume and discharge time shall be determined within the range that does not hinder the purpose of water supply, so that flood control in the downstream area can be immediately implemented upon the occurrence of a flood. 2. 2.5 Sedimentation (1) Sedimentation shall be determined by considering factors such as the determination of reservoir capacity, safety review of the dam, and review of discharge from the upstream of the reservoir during flood events. Design sedimentation should be estimated based on the sedimentation over a period of 100 years as a general rule. (2) Estimation of sedimentation shall refer to the "KDS 54 10 15" Dam Design Plan. Determination of Design Flood Discharge 2. 3.1 Design Flood Criteria (1) Hydraulic structures are exposed to damage from floods. It is impossible and economically impractical to completely defend against floods, so the design of hydraulic structures must consider some degree of flood risk. For design purposes, it is necessary to define the maximum flood corresponding to an acceptable risk, which is referred to as the design flood. (2) The design flood discharge is the peak flood discharge estimated as the design rainfall intensity adopted for hydraulic structure design or river management after comprehensively considering flood characteristics, flood frequency, the possibility of flood damage, and socioeconomic factors, and representing the crest of the hydrograph. (3) This design flood discharge for dams is essential data for determining dam elevation, reviewing dam safety, reviewing flood control capacity, and flood tracing. Furthermore, dams are the largest hydraulic structures, and design standards must be strengthened because the loss of life and property caused by dam failure due to factors such as overtopping is significant. Moreover, due to global warming and El Niño phenomena, extreme and intense rainfall events occur frequently, so the probable maximum flood discharge should be considered for large dams. (4) The design flood discharge of a dam shall be the largest value among the 200-year probable flood discharge, the historical maximum flood discharge, and the local maximum flood discharge. However, for agricultural weirs (hereinafter referred to as “weirs”), the flow rate increased by 20% of the design flood discharge shall be used as the standard. (5) Dams of a certain scale (watershed area of 2,500 ha, reservoir capacity of 5 million m3) or dams for which significant human and property damage is anticipated due to failure (e.g., those located downstream of cities or densely populated areas, or national important facilities) shall use the probable maximum flood (PMF) as the design flood discharge. 2. 3. 1.1 Classification of Hydraulic Structures (1) The types of hydraulic structures are categorized based on factors such as the scale and safety of the structures, and are generally classified as follows based on the potential damage resulting from structural failure. ① Small-scale hydraulic structures: In the event of failure, there is almost no loss of life, and the damage is limited to the cost of replacing or repairing the structure. Examples include drainage channels, urban stormwater drainage systems, airport drainage facilities, road culverts, urban stormwater retention basins, small river levees, small dam spillways and auxiliary facilities. ② Medium-scale hydraulic structures: Failure may result in slight loss of life, and the damage is within the financial capacity of the structure's manager or owner. Examples include hydropower facilities, irrigation canals, medium-sized dams and reservoirs, urban flood control basins, and railway culverts. ③ Large-scale hydraulic structures: Failure would result in significant loss of life and widespread damage. Representative examples include large-scale multipurpose dams or reservoirs, large river levees, spillways, nuclear power plants, large-scale irrigation canals, and weirs. 2. 3. 1.2 Design Frequency (1) The optimal design frequency for hydraulic structures should be selected to balance the cost of construction with safety, while also considering the potential damage from the failure of the hydraulic structure. It is generally determined based on factors such as the importance of the structure, its design life, and economic considerations. (2) The design frequency for the design of hydraulic structures can be determined based on the concept of estimated limits and structure-specific design frequencies. (3) The estimated limit is defined as the maximum size of a hydrological event that can occur at a given location, utilizing the maximum available hydrological information. The frequency can be set considering the size of the hydraulic structure, or, for events exceeding the design frequency, the maximum hydrometeorologically possible value can be estimated using historical hydrological events. (4) The final hydrological design value should be determined based on engineering judgment and the designer's experience. This determination requires risk analysis of design rainfall and flood flow, cost-benefit analysis of flood control, and decisions based on experience and standard criteria. (5) The criteria for determining the hydrological design scale should be based on the engineering judgment and experience of the hydraulic designer. In particular, when determining the design value of hydraulic structures for extreme hydrological events, engineering judgment should be combined with a cost-benefit analysis of the reproduction period to minimize the annual average cost, as well as the type of structure, its importance, and the degree of development in the flood area. (6) Dams, although large structures, are more appropriately subject to different criteria based on their size rather than a one-size-fits-all approach. The scale of agricultural dams in Korea varies greatly, with reservoir capacities ranging from tens of thousands to tens of millions of cubic meters. Therefore, for dams with a reservoir capacity of 5 million m³ or a watershed area of 2,500 ha or more, it should be assumed that the maximum probable flood discharge is entering, considering the safety of the dam against extreme rainfall. And for small dams with a height of less than 15m, the design frequency should be applied considering the land use status of the downstream area expected to be inundated when the dam overflows and the economic feasibility of restoring losses from dam failure. 2. 3. 1.3 Determination of Design Flood Volume - Basic Principles (1) Flood waters required for dam design include inflow design flood from the watershed to the dam, spillway discharge design flood, and design flood for drainage facilities, among others. (2) In domestic practice, a design flood standard for the outlet channel is adopted as 120% of the inflow flood volume of the reservoir with a 200-year return period (500~1,000 year frequency) for a fill dam and is used as the outflow volume obtained through reservoir routing. However, due to the recent frequent occurrence of extreme rainfall events, the probability of exceeding such frequency flood volumes during the dam’s lifespan has increased. In the case of large dams, the determination of the outlet channel or the dam crest elevation may be based on the Probable Maximum Flood (PMF) to consider the anticipated damage scale resulting from the hypothetical failure of the dam. (3) The Probable Maximum Flood (PMF) refers to the flood volume caused by the Probable Maximum Precipitation. The Probable Maximum Precipitation in a watershed is defined as “the theoretical maximum precipitation that can physically occur within a given duration, at a specific location, over a given watershed area, during any designated period within a year.” (4) The design flood volume for a dam spillway is determined by selecting the maximum outflow volume at the spillway section through flood routing in the reservoir, using the inflow hydrograph corresponding to the design frequency for the reservoir. 2. 3. 1.4 Considerations for Determining Design Flood for Agricultural Dams (1) The calculation of the inflow design flood hydrograph for a dam should be performed considering the characteristics of the maximum rainfall event according to the geographical location of the dam basin, the watershed area, the soil and vegetation cover and runoff distribution characteristics of the basin, and future climate change vulnerability. The flood scale of the basin varies greatly depending on the topography, geology, and rainfall characteristics according to the geographical location of the basin. Therefore, when determining the design flood, it is necessary to consider these influencing factors of the target basin. (2) Probable Maximum Precipitation (PMP) is a rainfall event that can occur hydro-meteorologically within a specified duration over a specific rainfall area at a specific location, and serves as the reference rainfall for determining the inflow design flood for large dams. The probable maximum precipitation is determined by undergoing an enclosure process through maximizing the moisture of the occurred extreme rainfall and rainfall transposition, utilizing the relationship of rainfall depth-rainfall area-duration (DAD) of the occurred extreme rainfall, and is represented as the relationship of maximum probable precipitation by rainfall duration and watershed area (PMP-DAD). (3) In the case of Korea, the PMP announced by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport, etc., can be used as the reference precipitation for design. The PMP map is prepared in the form of an isopleth across the country for rainfall durations of 1, 2, 6, 12, 24, 48, and 72 hours, and rainfall areas of 25, 100, 200, 1,000, 2,000, 10,000, and 20,000㎢, making it effective for PMP estimation and verification. (4) In accordance with Article 47-2 of the "Act on Agriculture, Rural Areas and Food Industry," scientific future meteorological data can be utilized for determining the design flood in areas vulnerable to climate change, as a result of the assessment of the impact and vulnerability of agriculture and rural areas to climate change. If necessary, expert consultation may be obtained to secure and produce national climate change standard scenarios or verified future meteorological data for application. (5) The watershed map, which indicates the upper stream river network and watershed boundary of the dam basin, is prepared from the terrain map, and should comprehensively display data on watershed characteristics such as watershed area, river channel slope and length, and data on existing hydrological observation stations (rainfall, water level, discharge). In addition, data on soil distribution, vegetation cover, and land use status of the basin should be obtained from the soil map and land use map. To increase the reliability of the watershed map, a field survey should be conducted. 2. 3. 1.5 Method for Determining Probable Maximum Flood (PMF) (1) The Probable Maximum Flood (PMF) is determined by first determining the Probable Maximum Precipitation (PMP) that considers the area scale of the dam basin, the design rainfall duration, and the spatiotemporal distribution corresponding to the PMP. Then, it is calculated through an outflow calculation process using rainfall-runoff relationship models such as the unit hydrograph method and the basin flood routing method, and expressed as the inflow design flood hydrograph to the dam. (2) The PMP for the dam basin is determined from the PMP data prepared through a hydrological and meteorological analysis, corresponding to the area scale and design rainfall duration of the dam basin. (3) This is distributed spatially and temporally to create the Probable Maximum Storm (PMS) for use in outflow calculations. (4) Once the PMP for the dam basin is determined, a PMF hydrograph, which represents the temporal distribution of the PMF, is calculated using a rainfall-runoff relationship model. Commonly used rainfall-runoff relationship models include the unit hydrograph method, the composite unit hydrograph method, and the basin flood routing method. 2. 3. 1.6 Calculation Method for Flood Peaks with Specified Frequency (1) The principle for calculating flood peaks with specified frequency is to interpret the frequency of the historical peak flow data series. However, when flood data is unavailable, a design rainfall is determined through frequency analysis, and then a rainfall-runoff model is used to calculate the design flood peak. (2) A flood with a specified frequency is a flood of a certain magnitude, and its frequency of occurrence is indicated by the average return period. In the design of small dams or water infrastructure, frequency floods are sometimes used to reduce excessive construction costs when designing based on the maximum possible flood, considering that the economic and social damage from the virtual failure of these structures would not be severe. (3) In principle, flood peaks with specified frequency are calculated by establishing an annual maximum flood series when long-term flood data is measured at the dam site, performing frequency analysis (frequency analysis) probabilistically to obtain a frequency curve, and then estimating the flood discharge for each return period by interpolation or extrapolation. However, in Korea, long-term flood records at dam sites are mostly unavailable, making it difficult to obtain flood peaks with specified frequency through frequency analysis. Therefore, a common method is to analyze the frequency of relatively abundant rainfall data to determine the frequency rainfall amount for each rainfall duration in the dam basin and then determine the flood peak with specified frequency using an appropriate rainfall-runoff model. The assumption of this method is that the frequency of occurrence of a flood is the same as the frequency of occurrence of the rainfall that causes it. However, considering the nonlinearity of the rainfall-runoff relationship, there are issues, but since there are no other alternatives in practice, this method is widely applied. 2. 3.2 Flood Design Discharge Calculation Method (1) Floods required for dam design include design flood inflow from the watershed to the dam, overfall discharge design flood, and design flood of spillway facilities, etc. (2) The design flood discharge can be determined based on a design flood discharge with a recurrence interval of 200 years or more, or the probable maximum flood, considering recent extreme rainfall events and the anticipated damage scale due to the hypothetical failure of the dam. 2. 3. 2.1 Design Rainfall Amount Calculation (1) The design rainfall amount shall follow the results of the following probability rainfall amount calculation. (2) Rainfall data can be obtained through the National Water Resources Management Information System (WAMIS) and related organizations (Korea Meteorological Administration, Ministry of Environment, Korea Rural Community Corporation, Korea Water Resources Corporation, etc.), using the standard station numbers provided by WAMIS. (3) Rainfall data should be checked for outliers that deviate from typical data characteristics, and outliers should be identified, verified, and corrected. Annual maximum rainfall series for each duration shall be calculated and converted into arbitrary time rainfall data for use. (4) The method for calculating probability rainfall amounts is recommended to use the regional frequency analysis method presented in the Flood Calculation Standard Guidelines (Ministry of Environment), and the optimal probability distribution is to apply the GEV distribution as a principle, but it may be different considering the rainfall characteristics. (5) In areas where regional frequency analysis is difficult to perform and apply, such as islands and coastal areas, probability rainfall amounts can be calculated through site frequency analysis, and the optimal probability distribution for site frequency analysis is to apply the Gumbel distribution as a principle, but it may be different considering the rainfall characteristics. (6) The rainfall intensity formula for the probability rainfall amount corresponding to the arbitrary continuous 24-hour rainfall duration, considering the maximum rainfall condition, shall be calculated by adopting a General type or an entire series polynomial type with a high correlation coefficient. (7) Probability rainfall amounts are classified into point probability rainfall amounts and areal probability rainfall amounts, and watershed area. two If the area is 5.9 ㎢ or larger, the areal probability rainfall amount shall be applied. (8) The areal probability rainfall amount is calculated by multiplying the point probability rainfall amount by the areal reduction factor (Areal Reduction Factor, ARF) presented in the Flood Calculation Standard Guideline (Ministry of Environment), based on the flood calculation point. (9) The areal reduction factor is based on the watershed area of the flood calculation point and is applied consistently even when sub-watersheds are divided. 2. 3. 2.2 Temporal Distribution of Rainfall (1) Since probabilistic rainfall amounts represent the total rainfall for a specific duration, they do not reflect the temporal variations of rainfall within that duration. Therefore, to apply probabilistic rainfall amounts to runoff models for flood volume calculation, it is necessary to create and apply rainfall intensity-duration-frequency (IDF) curves that consider the temporal distribution within the duration, similar to observed rainfall. (2) The temporal distribution of rainfall is developed using the modified Huff method, which is based on extreme rainfall events, to consider the temporal and quantitative characteristics of rainfall for a specific location. The modified Huff dimensionless frequency curve is applied to the corresponding cluster area of each rainfall observation station. (3) Jeju Island considers the unique characteristics of its topography and total rainfall. two Apply the Huff dimensionless duration curve, calculated using rainfall events of 5.4㎜/hr or more (based on the entire annual time series data). (4) Among the nine forms of the dimensionless duration curve, categorized by Huff percentiles (probability 10∼90%), the peak rainfall intensity is applied as 50% of the value for the corresponding percentile. (5) For Huff method percentile selection, the 3rd quartile (among the 2nd and 3rd quartiles) is applied. 2. 3. 2.3 Effective Rainfall Calculation (1) Effective rainfall is determined by excluding the lost rainfall due to infiltration from the temporal distribution of rainfall to calculate direct runoff hydrographs using a unit hydrograph. (2) The calculation of effective rainfall adopts the NRCS method and applies adjusted runoff curve number criteria (AMC-Ⅱ condition) for Korean application (e.g., paddy fields, forests). (3) The antecedent moisture condition is applied with CNⅢ for the AMC-Ⅲ condition, which has the highest runoff rate, considering design safety. (4) Jeju Island applies the runoff curve number calculation method presented in the Jeju-type River Basic Plan and River Facility Management Manual (Jeju Island, 2013). 2. 3. 2.4 Design Flood Estimation (1) The flood runoff model fundamentally represents the rainfall-runoff relationship, and flood runoff is estimated from rainfall using a flood runoff model that can calculate peak flood discharge and flood hydrographs, etc. ① Interpretation of the flood hydrograph considers the following:

a. The flood hydrograph of a watershed can be calculated by calculating the direct runoff hydrograph through an effective rainfall hyetograph, and adding baseflow to it to calculate the flood hydrograph.

b. When a flood hydrograph is required in flood runoff analysis, hydrological/hydraulic models such as the unit hydrograph method or the hydraulic and hydrological design system K-HAS (KRC Hydraulics & Hydrology Analysis System) provided by the Korea Rural Community Corporation should be applied.

c. The estimation of the flood hydrograph can be obtained through various methods mentioned above, but its validity should be verified by actual measurements.

d. To accurately separate direct runoff and baseflow, it is necessary to know the geological hydrological characteristics of the watershed, such as the watershed boundary, geology of the groundwater aquifer, permeability, and transmissivity. However, baseflow has a relatively minor impact on peak flood discharge, and simplified methods such as the horizontal straight-line separation method, N-day method and modified N-day method, and recession curve method can be applied.

e. The critical duration is the rainfall duration that generates the maximum peak flow (for non-detention structures such as rivers) and the maximum storage ratio (for detention structures such as dams, the volume of water stored/total outflow volume) (Standard Guidelines for Flood Calculation, Ministry of Environment). The flood discharge is calculated for flood calculation points at intervals of 1 hour or 10 minutes, depending on the scale of the watershed, to determine the critical duration. 2.4 Location and Type of Agricultural Dams 2. 4.1 Agricultural Dam Site Selection (1) A dam is selected at a location within a river basin, from several candidate sites, that effectively performs various functions such as water supply, flood control, and small hydropower generation, while considering the effects of regulating river flow, topography, geology, hydrology, natural conditions, social conditions including population and economy, economic feasibility, and the preservation of the natural environment. (2) A dam’s location is primarily selected by considering the following conditions: ① A location where the required storage capacity and stored water volume can be secured. ② A location where leakage is unlikely and structural stability can be achieved. ③ A location where the construction cost per unit storage capacity is low and maintenance is convenient. ④ Other considerations include: a. Selecting a location that aligns with the purpose and type of the dam. b. Examining natural conditions such as topography and geology, as well as construction-related issues. c. Considering the social and economic impacts on the upstream and downstream areas of the dam. d. Reviewing it from the perspective of comprehensive water resource management. e. Considering harmony and preservation of the natural environment. 2. 4.2 Selection of Agricultural Dam Type (1) The dam type shall be selected based on considerations of safety, economy, and environmental friendliness, minimizing environmental damage and harmonizing with the surrounding landscape. (2) After comprehensively reviewing all conditions, both directly related to the dam site’s topography, geology, meteorology, hydrology, seismicity, and locally related conditions such as the type and quantity of fill materials and transportation, and indirectly related to the purpose of dam construction, scale, construction period, technology, labor, and construction equipment, the option that is both safe and cost-effective shall be selected. (3) Embankment dams can be constructed in areas with poor foundation or deep sedimentary layers, while agricultural concrete dams (hereinafter referred to as “concrete dams”) can be constructed on dam sites with good topography and geology. (4) Embankment dams have a wider foundation footprint than concrete dams, resulting in less stress on the ground and thus requiring less ground support. 2. 4.3 Agricultural Dam Type Selection and Alternative Comparison Method (1) When determining the dam type, the following items should be compared and reviewed. ① Dam Foundation: Examine the soil and rock quality (strength), rock distribution, presence of faults and fractured zones, etc., using soil and geological investigation data. In the case of an earthfill dam, the foundation resistance is lower than that of a concrete dam, so generally, the foundation is considered good if the dry density of the foundation is above the dry density on the compaction curve. ② Material Acquisition: For earthfill dams, construction materials are generally readily available near the dam site, but if unavoidable (e.g., designated as an environmental protection area), a borrow pit located far away may be selected. ③ Dam Type: A homogeneous earthfill dam is advantageous if high-quality clay and topsoil materials are readily available nearby, and a zoned earthfill dam is advantageous if suitable granular materials are readily available nearby. ④ Inundation Conditions: Review land acquisition, relocation roads, resettlement of displaced people, and public grievance measures based on the dam location and resulting inundated area. ⑤ Comprehensive Review: When two types of dam, an earthfill dam and a concrete dam, are proposed, comprehensively review them together with the environmental impact assessment results to select the dam type. 2.5 Eco-Friendly Dam Plan (1) The fundamental concept of the eco-friendly dam plan is to review environmental conservation plans through investigations necessary for water quality management of the dam and to minimize the impact on natural landscapes and major ecosystems when installing the dam. (2) It is also possible to consider plans for creating recreational and green spaces to provide places for local residents and nearby urban residents to relax, enjoy recreation, and educate their children, based on the environmental conservation of the dam basin. (3) To minimize the environmental impact of rural water development projects and to ensure that related facilities and spaces can be utilized for residents' lives, the best development strategies and alternatives will be prepared, and opinions from local residents and related organizations will be fully incorporated. (4) Eco-friendly dam and reservoir design will secure living, agricultural, industrial, and environmental water for rural areas while pursuing sustainable development that harmonizes with the natural environment and human activities, maximizing the public service functions of agriculture and ensuring harmony between environmental conservation and development. Assistance can be obtained from related specialized institutions and experts regarding water quality improvement, ecosystem conservation, and cultural heritage protection measures. To this end, environmental surveys should be conducted at each investigation stage and reflected in the design. 2. 5.1 Dam Construction and Environmental Conservation (1) Plans should be promoted to minimize negative impacts, including feasibility studies on the pre-selection of suitable sites and alternatives for dam development, along with prior environmental assessments. (2) The Prior Environmental Assessment System should be promoted to predict potential environmental issues, evaluate environmental impacts that can influence policy-making in the initial stages of dam construction planning, and establish reasonable and efficient business plans through conflict resolution with local communities, environmental organizations, and related agencies. 2. 5.2 Environmental Impacts of Dam Construction (1) Dam construction transforms a riverine environment into a reservoir environment, which can lead to changes in microclimate, river flow, and water quality, impacting the river ecosystem in the dam's watershed and downstream areas, as well as socio-economic and cultural aspects. (2) The environmental impacts of a dam are diverse, including physical, biological, and human impacts, and mitigation measures should be established. When constructing a dam, the following impacts should be comprehensively considered to minimize adverse environmental impacts. ① Meteorological Changes: It is possible that dam construction will cause changes in microclimate depending on the existing terrain, dam capacity, or reservoir area. ② Ecological Impacts: The formation of a reservoir can lead to changes in the flora and fauna along the shoreline and within the reservoir, including aquatic plants, aquatic insects, and fish. Some species may require adaptation to the new reservoir environment, necessitating prediction and management of the surrounding ecosystem's adaptation. ③ Water Quality Impacts: Mitigation measures should be established to manage changes in water quality, such as the settling of suspended solids in the reservoir and eutrophication due to storage. Specific water quality design during dam planning can be carried out in accordance with ‘KDS 67 40 40 Agricultural Irrigation Water Quality Management’ and ‘KDS 67 80 90 Agricultural Water Quality and Environmental Maintenance’. ④ Socio-economic Impacts: Consider the social issues, including the displacement of residents due to dam construction, and the impacts resulting from the aforementioned environmental changes in the area. ⑤ Cultural Impacts: Areas with historical, cultural, or unique natural landscapes are not suitable for dam construction. Cultural heritage assets recognized through prior evaluations should be documented and displayed, and dam planning changes or sufficient protection measures are necessary to protect cultural heritage and outstanding natural landscapes. 2. 5.3 Dam Construction and Environmental Conservation Plan (1) The construction of dams and reservoirs can affect human habitats, flora and fauna, upstream and downstream river areas, and surrounding terrain. Dam projects that neglect environmental impacts can lead to various ecological changes. Planning, design, and operation of dams need to minimize environmental impacts, and the potential negative impacts on the environment that conflict with the expected benefits of the dam should be carefully considered. (2) Dam planning should consider environmental impacts, including ecological impacts, water quality and health, geomorphological impacts, and political and social relationships. Rigorous analysis and prediction of environmental aspects are required. Furthermore, water resource planning and alternatives that can achieve the same primary objectives should be considered for all social, environmental, and economic factors. (3) An approach to environmental conservation should consider the shoreline of reservoirs and rivers, and surrounding forests, as a system within the context of a nationwide ecosystem network. Natural ecosystem monitoring should be conducted to address changes in the natural ecosystem that may result from dam construction. In addition, a post-completion evaluation plan should be established and implemented to ensure effective management and conservation after completion. The following methods can be considered as environmental conservation measures: ① Creation of ecological and cultural spaces around the dam ② Installation of habitats for fish and wildlife (e.g., Korean bullhead, lamprey, wild birds, otters) ③ Creation of ecological parks (eco-parks) and Biotopes ④ Fish passage facilities and other measures to protect migratory fish ⑤ Ecological restoration of reservoir slopes and improvement of lake scenery (e.g., revetments, aeration facilities) ⑥ Construction of facilities in harmony with nature ⑦ Post-construction ecological environment monitoring ⑧ Installation of ecological corridors (eco-corridors) ⑨ Post-project environmental impact assessment 2. 5.4 Comprehensive Development around Dams for Waterside Spaces (1) To secure waterside spaces that provide practical benefits to local residents and recreational areas for visitors, comprehensive development of the areas around dams is necessary. This project should be promoted through close consultation among relevant agencies, including the central government, local governments, local residents, and project implementers, to determine funding sources and construction/management entities. (2) Considerations for the comprehensive development of the areas around dams to secure waterside spaces include: ① Riverbank restoration ② Development of areas around the dam ③ Development of tourist areas around the dam ④ Development of natural recreation forests, nature learning centers, etc. ⑤ Creation of cultural villages ⑥ Relocation of cultural heritage within the submerged areas to establish a local cultural heritage village, etc. (3) Guidelines should be established to apply ecological conservation and landscape improvement design techniques (methods), mandating investment in a certain percentage of eco-friendly elements (or facilities) and developing and applying environmentally friendly dam landscape design techniques to maintain harmony with the surrounding nature. 2. 5.5 Eco-friendly Shoreline Restoration Plan (1) Shoreline restoration aims to improve the areas surrounding reservoirs, creating spaces for local residents and nearby city dwellers to relax, enjoy leisure activities, and educate their children. The plan will establish facility and space development plans, considering topography, space utilization, and land use, while minimizing negative environmental impacts. (2) Site conditions should be considered, including areas with good accessibility for educational, recreational, and leisure purposes, areas with well-preserved ecological environments and diverse habitats including water, and areas where natural environments have been damaged and require restoration. In response to changing social values, the shoreline of reservoirs, which have been neglected until now, should be preserved and improved to create a beautiful natural environment with water and forests, enhancing the reservoir’s recreational functions and providing relaxation spaces for local residents and city dwellers. 2. 5.6 Utilization of Reservoir Surface Facilities and Green Spaces (1) Reservoir Surface Water Management ① It is natural and a growing social demand to utilize reservoirs as tourist resources to effectively utilize local resources. Utilizing agricultural water facilities for tourism purposes is possible according to regulations based on the Rural Development Act. ② Dams owned by the Korea Rural Community Corporation can be used for other purposes and profit-generating businesses, but in this case, approval from the Minister of Food, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries is required to ensure that the use does not interfere with the original purpose and function of the property. Income generated from such use is allocated to the management entrustee. ③ Utilizing the reservoir surface as a tourist resource requires adjustments to the reservoir water level and water quality between the original purpose of the reservoir, which is irrigation, and rural tourism. (2) Water Level Adjustment and Maintenance ① From the perspective of maintaining the water level for tourism, it is advantageous to maintain the water level as high as possible. However, from the perspective of irrigation water, it is desirable to be able to release the necessary water freely. Therefore, a plan is needed to adjust and maintain the water level, taking care to avoid disruption to the irrigation plan. ② The contract with the tourism business operator should clearly state the principle of agricultural water priority. (3) Water Quality Preservation of the Reservoir ① Regarding water quality issues resulting from periodic concentrations of tourists in the created waterfront utilization areas and green spaces, strict regulations should be stipulated in the contract with the tourism industry. Generally, wastewater from restaurants should be treated separately and discharged into a stream or infiltrated into the ground using a soil treatment method. In many cases, wastewater from restaurants is treated separately and discharged into a stream or infiltrated into the ground using a soil treatment method. Even in this case, if the inflow volume from the indirect watershed is large and the circulation volume of the reservoir water is large, it can inhibit the rise in water temperature, which is a good condition. ② If the water level drops in summer, the water temperature will rise, and algae and plankton will flourish, leading to a deterioration of water quality. Therefore, pre-emptive measures are necessary. (4) Reservoir Surface Utilization Leisure Facilities ① Utilizing agricultural reservoirs to install “leisure” facilities can meet the needs of the people, promote balanced national development, and encourage healthy leisure activities. 2. 5.7 Shoreline Stabilization and Vegetation Treatment Plan for Slopes (1) Reservoir shorelines are transitional zones where terrestrial and freshwater ecosystems meet, providing a variety of habitats for various organisms. Therefore, shoreline stabilization measures should be reviewed, considering the natural ecosystem to prevent the separation of terrestrial and freshwater ecosystems. (2) The reservoir shorelines should be restored to be ecologically healthy, harmonized with the natural landscape, and enhance their usability as recreational and educational spaces for residents. The shoreline stabilization techniques aim to ecologically restore the reservoir shorelines, which play an ecologically important role. (3) Regarding the reservoir shoreline slopes and the inflow area of the stream into the reservoir, consideration should be given to appropriate slope treatment methods that prevent erosion caused by fluctuations in stream water levels and waves on the water surface, and harmonize with the surrounding environment. ① Priority should be given to reviewing visually sensitive protrusions and ecological habitat areas for planting. ② When selecting species, select those that are easy to maintain and adaptable to the natural environment. ③ Consider the soil distribution and slope gradient around the reservoir. ④ Minimize the input of artificial energy when the soil environment changes. ⑤ Consider the surrounding vegetation and planting objectives. ⑥ Consider the impact of human use and artificial interference. 2. 5.8 Riparian zone (gentle slope from low water level to high water level) planting plan and design (1) At the bottom of the reservoir, there are dam structures and spillways, and at the top, there is an inflow river. Around the reservoir, freshwater wetlands, grasslands, or farmland and forests generally appear in a stepwise manner. Therefore, the planting plan is established and designed by considering these land cover conditions and introducing landscape ecological principles. 2. 5.9 Access and Relocation Roads (1) When selecting the route, sufficient consideration shall be given to preventing disruption of animal movement and minimizing habitat damage to the reservoir shoreline and adjacent areas resulting from the construction of access and relocation roads to the reservoir. (2) The planning and design of vegetation on the slopes of access and relocation roads and ecological underpasses shall consider the stability of the road, terrain conditions, and economic feasibility, and shall examine the installation of animal (including amphibian) crossing passages and habitat protection facilities. (3) The slopes resulting from the construction of the reservoir relocation road are visually detrimental due to the exposure of soil or rock, and there is a risk of collapse. Therefore, slope stabilization facilities should be used in conjunction with vegetation engineering techniques using natural materials to harmonize with the surrounding landscape. (4) Through thorough biological surveys of the surrounding area, identify species, habitat locations, and movement routes, and ensure that the road bypasses these areas or, if unavoidable, provides animal crossing passages. 2. 5.10 Downstream River Improvement Plan (1) The potential reduction of downstream river flow due to dams and reservoirs should be carefully reviewed. In particular, environmental water should be supplied to ensure adequate water depth and flow for the survival of fish and wildlife even during dry seasons, and water quality should be preserved through the maintenance and improvement of the riverbed and banks. (2) Small-scale hydropower development should be considered based on the size of the minimum streamflow. At this time, environmental water should be determined by simultaneously reviewing the recreational water requirements for securing recreational space in the downstream river to improve the river landscape and foster community sentiment. (3) The flood control function and environmental function of a river are to some extent conflicting. River environment elements such as the ecosystem, landscape, and recreational value are significantly affected by the materials of the riverbed and banks. Therefore, in downstream river improvement projects associated with reservoirs, a variety of materials should be selected according to the purpose, fully reflecting the river characteristics and local conditions. The river environment elements should be preserved and improved, and optimal materials should be compared and selected or combined for application to prevent erosion during flood seasons. (4) In the design or management of medium-sized irrigation reservoirs, measures should be taken to supply maintenance water to prevent the drying up of the downstream river and maintain the river ecosystem. 2.6 Economic Evaluation (1) The costs associated with dam construction are divided into direct costs (or direct expenses) and indirect costs (or indirect expenses). They can also be classified as tangible costs and intangible costs. (2) Costs are broadly categorized as total project costs and maintenance costs, with total project costs including construction costs, compensation costs, incidental costs, and renovation costs. (3) Detailed aspects of the economic evaluation of dam construction shall follow ‘KDS 67 40 20 Non-River Engineering’ and ‘KDS 54 10 15 Dam Design Planning.’ 3.
